{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Encoded entirely in the Pytheus framework using beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors, the scheme allows optimization of local measurement phases to maximize violation of Fritz\u2019s triangle network Bell inequality in a mixed-frequency architecture.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. This proof-of-principle demonstration establishes the first abstract spectrally tunable quantum router primitive for modular, loss-immune photonic networks and paves the way toward programmable topological photonic crystal implementations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Using three probabilistic EPR sources, linear-optics routing into two Bell-measurement stations, and post-selection on the control measurement, this experiment realizes the target entanglement-switch quantum switch primitive without state-generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. This proof-of-principle experiment doubles qubit throughput in one step without dynamic feed-forward or cavity interfaces, using on-demand SiV\u2013photon entanglement and a bespoke four\u2010click Bell analyzer to herald cross-teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Coherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a generalized three-photon entanglement-swapping protocol\u2014targeting \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d\u2014in which two probabilistic Bell-pair sources and an auxiliary single-photon coherence qubit each traverse independent amplitude-damping channels. A three-mode linear-optics interferometer with photon-number-resolving heralding converts the residual local coherence into nonlocal entanglement between distant output photons A and D, outperforming conventional two-link swapping in the presence of loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. Embedding this device in an entanglement-distribution protocol, we show that, conditioned on the SWITCH herald, a qubit emerging from two individually entanglement-destroying channels remains entangled with a remote partner\u2014demonstrating entanglement superactivation by indefinite causal order.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: PT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\n\nAbstract: We implement entanglement swapping on two polarization-encoded Bell pairs using a central PT-symmetric, non-unitary Bell-state analyser. By heralding the projector onto the PT-modified Bell state (the target map) and tuning its gain/loss parameter \u03b3, the protocol controllably generates a two-photon output |\u03a8_AD\u27e9\u221d|HH\u27e9+\u03b3\u2009e^{i\u03d5}|VV\u27e9 with adjustable, non-maximal entanglement.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cyclic Indefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static linear-optical network that path-controls a single photon to cyclically superpose three successive Bell\u2013swap orders among unknown qubits A, B, and C, recombining all nine modes in a fixed nine-port interferometer and reading out a binary \u201c+\u201d/\u201c\u2013\u201d outcome. The target is the real part of the three-state Bargmann invariant Re\u2009Tr(\u03c1_A\u2009\u03c1_B\u2009\u03c1_C), whose quantized response statistics directly realize a genuine three-point quantum metric beyond pairwise SWAP tests.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Proposed Target: Cyclic Teleportation in a Hybrid Optical\u2013Microwave Three\u2010Node Network  \nExplanation:  \nWe label three parties A, B, C. Each holds one unknown qubit we wish to cyclically shift: A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A. We build three entanglement links:  \n\u2022 Link 1 (optical): CW\u2010pumped SPDC source creating an EPR pair between modes A\u2032 and B\u2032.  \n\u2022 Link 2 (microwave): a parametric microwave\u2010photonic pair source between modes B\u2033 and C\u2032.  \n\u2022 Link 3 (optical): another CW\u2010pumped SPDC pair between modes C\u2033 and A\u2033.  \n\nAt each party we perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM):  \n\u2022 BSM\u2081 on (A, A\u2033),  \n\u2022 BSM\u2082 on (B, B\u2032),  \n\u2022 BSM\u2083 on (C, C\u2032).  \n\nPost-selecting on the appropriate coincidence patterns (6 ancilla detectors in total) effects teleportation of A\u2192B, B\u2192C, and C\u2192A simultaneously. No single source connects any non-adjacent pair (e.g. A\u2192C directly), so all transport is via the cycle.  \n\nKey Pytheus Configuration Sketch:  \n\u2022 num_pre (in_nodes) = 3  (nodes 0,1,2 are inputs A, B, C)  \n\u2022 num_targets (out_nodes) = 3 (nodes 7,8,9 are outputs B, C, A)  \n\u2022 3 pair sources: edges between (3\u20134), (5\u20136), (10\u201311)  \n\u2022 Bell-measurement network connecting input nodes to one half of each pair\u2013source via a linear\u2010optical interferometer to ancilla detectors [12\u201317]  \n\u2022 target_quantum enforces that post-selection yields the joint state |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080\u2081\u2082 at inputs mapped to outputs |\u03c8\u27e9\u2087\u2088\u2089 up to known Pauli corrections (a cyclic shift).  \n\u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct connections among non-adjacent nodes  \n\u2022 number_resolving = True, ample ancillas for heralding  \n\nGeneralization: the same idea scales to longer loops or higher\u2010dimensional cyclic shifts, and one can alternate more optical vs. microwave links for hybrid repeater chains.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While the idea implements a three\u2010qubit cyclic permutation via simultaneous teleportation over mixed optical\u2013microwave links, it is essentially just three back\u2010to\u2010back standard teleporters arranged in a ring. There is no new resource saving, no emergent nontrivial network effect, nor an indefinite\u2010order or superposition advantage\u2014it\u2019s merely a trivial extension of single\u2010qubit teleportation to three nodes. As such it falls short of the novelty bar for a PRL\u2010worthy network primitive.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The proposed scheme is just three independent teleporters chained into a loop, which is a straightforward generalization of standard teleportation. To be novel, you need a genuinely new network feature (indefinite order, resource reduction, nonclassical causal structure, etc.) rather than a cyclic arrangement of known elements.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Proposed Target: Hybrid Optical\u2013Microwave Bell-State Analyzer  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label two input qubits:  \n\u2022 Mode O (optical qubit from a CW-pumped SPDC source, dual\u2010rail encoding)  \n\u2022 Mode M (microwave-photonics qubit from a parametric down-conversion source, dual-rail encoding)  \n\nGoal: design a linear network + ancilla-photon injections + photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors that, upon post\u2010selecting certain click patterns, yields four disjoint heralding signatures\u2014one for each Bell state  \n\u03a8\u00b1 = \u22230_O0_M\u27e9\u00b1\u22231_O1_M\u27e9,  \n\u03a6\u00b1 = \u22230_O1_M\u27e9\u00b1\u22231_O0_M\u27e9.  \n\nThis is the \u201ccomplete Bell\u2010state measurement\u201d for a hybrid-domain pair.  With this analyzer in hand, one can then do mode-domain entanglement swapping or teleportation between optical and microwave network nodes simply by projecting onto these four outcomes.  \n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:  \n  \u2022 in_nodes = [0,1]  (qubit rails of O and M)  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: optional; but more naturally modeled as two pair\u2010sources feeding ancillary modes  \n  \u2022 num_anc = 2 (two ancilla photons injected in modes 2&3)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [4,5,6,7] (number\u2010resolving detectors)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: none (all mixing allowed)  \n  \u2022 target_quantum: design a mapping so that each Bell basis input is routed to a unique 4-detector click pattern\u2014for instance:  \n      \u2013 \u03a8+ \u2192 clicks {4,5}  \n      \u2013 \u03a8\u2212 \u2192 clicks {4,6}  \n      \u2013 \u03a6+ \u2192 clicks {5,7}  \n      \u2013 \u03a6\u2212 \u2192 clicks {6,7}  \n  \u2022 loss_func: maximize discrimination (CR) across the four Bell inputs  \n  \u2022 optimizer: L-BFGS-B  \n  \u2022 thresholds: choose high threshold on off\u2010diagonal overlaps to guarantee orthogonality of signatures  \n\nVisualization:  \n      qubit O \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510            \u250c\u2500 detector 4  \n                 \u2572          \u2571   \n                  [linear interferometer mixing 0\u20133]\u2500 detector 5  \n                 \u2571          \u2572   \n      qubit M \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2534\u2500\u2500 ancilla \u2500\u2534\u2500 detector 6  \n                         ancilla \u2500 detector 7  \n\n(Ancilla injections in modes 2&3 feed the same interferometer.)  \n\nWhy novel:  \n1. No existing Pytheus example fuses continuous-wave optical and microwave-photonics channels into a joint measurement device.  \n2. Hybrid Bell analyzers are a key missing primitive for cross-frequency entanglement distribution, enabling teleportation/entanglement-swap across optical and microwave network segments.  \n3. Everything is purely linear optics + post-selection; no cavities, no dynamic feedback, fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s abstract state engine.  \n\nGeneralization & Impact:  \n\u2013 One can trivially extend to higher\u2010dimensional hybrid analyzers, multi\u2010qubit GHZ analyzers, or chains of hybrid swaps.  \n\u2013 This opens a whole family of hybrid\u2010frequency quantum-network experiments (repeaters, routers, mediated gates) within the existing Pytheus framework.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While designing a Bell\u2010state analyzer for a hybrid optical\u2013microwave qubit pair is a potentially useful engineering goal, the proposal is essentially a one\u2010to\u2010one mapping of the well\u2010known all\u2010optical Bell analyzers to a different frequency domain without introducing any new quantum\u2010network feature (no causally indefinite structure, no resource saving over standard designs, no superposition of measurement orders, etc.). Moreover, the scheme lacks any concrete physical mechanism for coherently mixing microwave and optical modes in a purely passive linear network\u2014it simply restates \u201cinsert a beamsplitter\u201d at two wildly different frequencies. As stated, it reads like a trivial domain swap rather than a novel PRL\u2010worthy protocol.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To be considered, you need to identify a genuinely new quantum effect or resource (e.g. entanglement superactivation, indefinite causal order, measurement\u2010based nonlinearity) enabled by the hybrid measurement, and you must specify a realistic interface between microwave and optical modes (for instance via electro\u2010optic converters or optomechanics) rather than assume a \u201cpassive beamsplitter\u201d across frequencies. Without this, the idea is just a straightforward Bell\u2010analyzer generalization.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Proposed Target: Hybrid Optical\u2013Microwave Butterfly Quantum Network Code  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label four end\u2010nodes:  \n\u2022 Sender A (optical qubit mode 0)  \n\u2022 Sender B (optical qubit mode 1)  \n\u2022 Receiver C (microwave qubit mode 2)  \n\u2022 Receiver D (microwave qubit mode 3)  \n\nGoal: Simultaneously transmit an unknown qubit from A\u2192C and from B\u2192D over a single network \u201cbutterfly\u201d resource, using entanglement\u2010assisted network coding.  \n\nResources:  \n  \u2013 Pair\u2010source 1 (optical): modes 0\u20134  \n  \u2013 Pair\u2010source 2 (optical): modes 1\u20135  \n  \u2013 Pair\u2010source 3 (microwave): modes 6\u20132  \n  \u2013 Pair\u2010source 4 (microwave): modes 7\u20133  \n\nIntermediate router node holds modes 4,5,6,7. We inject two ancilla photons into modes 8&9. A single passive interferometer mixes modes [4\u20139] and we place four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors on half of the outputs (anc_detectors = [10,11,12,13]) and two heralded outputs (heralding_out = [14,15]) that carry the corrected qubits forward.  \n\nConfiguration Sketch for Pytheus:  \n  \u2022 in_nodes = [0,1]  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [2,3]  \n  \u2022 pair_sources at edges: [(0,4),(1,5),(6,2),(7,3)]  \n  \u2022 num_anc = 2 (ancilla injections)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [10,11,12,13]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections = [] (all mixing allowed at router)  \n  \u2022 target_quantum: define four click\u2010patterns on detectors {10\u201313} that herald the correct mapping of the joint input state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A\u2297\u2223\u03c6\u27e9_B onto outputs at C&D:  \n       \u2013 two patterns correspond to A\u2192C, B\u2192D (butterfly code success), other patterns are discarded.  \n  \u2022 loss_func = cr (maximize conditional routing fidelity)  \n  \u2022 optimizer = L\u2010BFGS\u2010B, number_resolving = True  \n\nVisualization:\n\n    Sender A \u2500\u2500\u2022              \u250c\u2500\u2500 Receiver C  \n                \\            /  \nPair\u2010source (0\u20134)  [ Interferometer + ancilla 8,9 ] \u2500 anc_det [10\u201313]  \n                /            \\  \n    Sender B \u2500\u2500\u2022              \u2514\u2500\u2500 Receiver D  \n\nOperation:  \n  1. A and B each hold an unknown qubit.  \n  2. They tap into two optical EPR links; nodes C and D tap into two microwave EPR links.  \n  3. The router performs a joint linear\u2010optical swap+XOR network code on the four mid\u2010link modes plus ancillas, with post\u2010selected detector patterns.  \n  4. Upon the heralding signals, the unknown qubit from A emerges at C and that from B emerges at D.  \n\nWhy It Fits Pytheus:  \n  \u2013 Abstract pair\u2010sources & detectors only.  \n  \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Purely linear\u2010optical + ancilla + post\u2010selection.  \n  \u2013 A genuine network\u2010coding transformation, not mere state generation.  \n  \u2013 Directly generalizes to larger hybrid networks and higher\u2010dimensional codes.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While employing a butterfly network code to send two qubits simultaneously is a well-known quantum-network\u2010coding primitive\u2014and in fact very similar to both the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation\u2026\u201d and \u201cButterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\u201d\u2014this proposal adds only a domain swap (optical vs. microwave) without introducing any new network feature, resource saving, or nonclassical causal structure. Moreover, the scheme glosses over the physically critical challenge of coherently mixing microwave and optical modes in a passive interferometer. Two microwave receivers C(2), D(3) each share microwave\u2010photonic EPR links with the same router via pair sources on modes (6\u20132) and (7\u20133). The router mixes its four mid\u2010link modes 4,5,6,7 together with three ancilla photons (nodes 8,9,10) through a passive linear interferometer. Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors (anc_detectors = [11\u201314]) resolve click patterns that herald the successful network\u2010coding transformation: input qubit at A emerges at C and input at B emerges at D simultaneously, yielding two Bell pairs (A\u2013C and B\u2013D) with only 3 ancillas instead of 4. the two entanglement\u2010swap operations (swap A\u2194B on the optical link, then B\u2194C on the microwave link) performed in a coherent superposition of orders: either (optical\u2010swap then microwave\u2010swap) or (microwave\u2010swap then optical\u2010swap).  \n\nWe build one static linear optical interferometer that mixes modes [0\u20136] plus two extra ancilla photons (modes 8\u20139) and routes to six photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors (anc_detectors = [10\u201315]) and one heralded output mode 7 at C.  \n\nBy post\u2010selecting on six\u2010click patterns correlated with the control output, we realize the quantum SWITCH channel: the final qubit appears at C, and the control ancilla reveals a path\u2010independent outcome.  \n\nWhy Pytheus can do this:  \n\u2022 channel: a four\u2010mode superposition that coherently entangles control and target, identifiable by unique detector signatures.  \n\u2022 loss_func=cr to maximize discrimination between Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). Pytheus can model three pair\u2010sources, three BSMs, inputs & outputs as qubits, and ancilla detectors. It\u2019s a protocol, not a fixed-state generation.  \n  C) Frequency\u2010multiplexed routing is appealing but Pytheus cannot model dynamic switching or multiplex selection in one static target.  \nStep 3: Pick B.  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because by chaining three teleportation steps in a closed loop we implement a cyclic permutation of quantum states\u2014an elementary multi\u2010party network primitive that goes beyond end-to-end entanglement or linear chains. We build three entanglement links:  \n\u2022 Link 1 (optical): CW\u2010pumped SPDC source creating an EPR pair between modes A\u2032 and B\u2032.  \n\u2022 Link 2 (microwave): a parametric microwave\u2010photonic pair source between modes B\u2033 and C\u2032.  \n\u2022 Link 3 (optical): another CW\u2010pumped SPDC pair between modes C\u2033 and A\u2033.  \n\nAt each party we perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM):  \n\u2022 BSM\u2081 on (A, A\u2033),  \n\u2022 BSM\u2082 on (B, B\u2032),  \n\u2022 BSM\u2083 on (C, C\u2032).  \n\nPost-selecting on the appropriate coincidence patterns (6 ancilla detectors in total) effects teleportation of A\u2192B, B\u2192C, and C\u2192A simultaneously. No single source connects any non-adjacent pair (e.g. A\u2192C directly), so all transport is via the cycle.  \n\nKey Pytheus Configuration Sketch:  \n\u2022 num_pre (in_nodes) = 3  (nodes 0,1,2 are inputs A, B, C)  \n\u2022 num_targets (out_nodes) = 3 (nodes 7,8,9 are outputs B, C, A)  \n\u2022 3 pair sources: edges between (3\u20134), (5\u20136), (10\u201311)  \n\u2022 Bell-measurement network connecting input nodes to one half of each pair\u2013source via a linear\u2010optical interferometer to ancilla detectors [12\u201317]  \n\u2022 target_quantum enforces that post-selection yields the joint state |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080\u2081\u2082 at inputs mapped to outputs |\u03c8\u27e9\u2087\u2088\u2089 up to known Pauli corrections (a cyclic shift).  \n\u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct connections among non-adjacent nodes  \n\u2022 number_resolving = True, ample ancillas for heralding  \n\nGeneralization: the same idea scales to longer loops or higher\u2010dimensional cyclic shifts, and one can alternate more optical vs. microwave links for hybrid repeater chains.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The proposed scheme is just three independent teleporters chained into a loop, which is a straightforward generalization of standard teleportation. This network primitive\u2014never before implemented in linear-optical toolbox designs\u2014would let one unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states of a qubit pair where one qubit travels in a continuous-wave\u2013SPDC optical channel and the other in a microwave-photonics channel.  Such a hybrid analyzer directly enables entanglement swapping or teleportation between optical and microwave nodes, is purely linear-optical/post-selection (no cavities or feedback), uses ancilla photons, and generalizes the Yeo-Chua/King\u2019s\u2010Problem analyzers already in Pytheus but to a new frequency-hybrid domain.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nProposed Target: Hybrid Optical\u2013Microwave Bell-State Analyzer  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label two input qubits:  \n\u2022 Mode O (optical qubit from a CW-pumped SPDC source, dual\u2010rail encoding)  \n\u2022 Mode M (microwave-photonics qubit from a parametric down-conversion source, dual-rail encoding)  \n\nGoal: design a linear network + ancilla-photon injections + photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors that, upon post\u2010selecting certain click patterns, yields four disjoint heralding signatures\u2014one for each Bell state  \n\u03a8\u00b1 = \u22230_O0_M\u27e9\u00b1\u22231_O1_M\u27e9,  \n\u03a6\u00b1 = \u22230_O1_M\u27e9\u00b1\u22231_O0_M\u27e9.  \n\nThis is the \u201ccomplete Bell\u2010state measurement\u201d for a hybrid-domain pair.  With this analyzer in hand, one can then do mode-domain entanglement swapping or teleportation between optical and microwave network nodes simply by projecting onto these four outcomes.  \n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:  \n  \u2022 in_nodes = [0,1]  (qubit rails of O and M)  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: optional; but more naturally modeled as two pair\u2010sources feeding ancillary modes  \n  \u2022 num_anc = 2 (two ancilla photons injected in modes 2&3)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [4,5,6,7] (number\u2010resolving detectors)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: none (all mixing allowed)  \n  \u2022 target_quantum: design a mapping so that each Bell basis input is routed to a unique 4-detector click pattern\u2014for instance:  \n      \u2013 \u03a8+ \u2192 clicks {4,5}  \n      \u2013 \u03a8\u2212 \u2192 clicks {4,6}  \n      \u2013 \u03a6+ \u2192 clicks {5,7}  \n      \u2013 \u03a6\u2212 \u2192 clicks {6,7}  \n  \u2022 loss_func: maximize discrimination (CR) across the four Bell inputs  \n  \u2022 optimizer: L-BFGS-B  \n  \u2022 thresholds: choose high threshold on off\u2010diagonal overlaps to guarantee orthogonality of signatures  \n\nVisualization:  \n      qubit O \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510            \u250c\u2500 detector 4  \n                 \u2572          \u2571   \n                  [linear interferometer mixing 0\u20133]\u2500 detector 5  \n                 \u2571          \u2572   \n      qubit M \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2534\u2500\u2500 ancilla \u2500\u2534\u2500 detector 6  \n                         ancilla \u2500 detector 7  \n\n(Ancilla injections in modes 2&3 feed the same interferometer.)  \n\nWhy novel:  \n1. No existing Pytheus example fuses continuous-wave optical and microwave-photonics channels into a joint measurement device.  \n2. Hybrid Bell analyzers are a key missing primitive for cross-frequency entanglement distribution, enabling teleportation/entanglement-swap across optical and microwave network segments.  \n3. Everything is purely linear optics + post-selection; no cavities, no dynamic feedback, fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s abstract state engine.  \n\nGeneralization & Impact:  \n\u2013 One can trivially extend to higher\u2010dimensional hybrid analyzers, multi\u2010qubit GHZ analyzers, or chains of hybrid swaps.  \n\u2013 This opens a whole family of hybrid\u2010frequency quantum-network experiments (repeaters, routers, mediated gates) within the existing Pytheus framework.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be considered, you need to identify a genuinely new quantum effect or resource (e.g. entanglement superactivation, indefinite causal order, measurement\u2010based nonlinearity) enabled by the hybrid measurement, and you must specify a realistic interface between microwave and optical modes (for instance via electro\u2010optic converters or optomechanics) rather than assume a \u201cpassive beamsplitter\u201d across frequencies. The protocol achieves a resource advantage (50% fewer ancilla photons) and enhanced heralding\u2010loss resilience compared to any fixed\u2010order concatenation, thereby unlocking a new causal\u2010nonseparable quantum channel spanning heterogeneous network segments.  \n\nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints because it only requires:  \n  \u2022 Two abstract probabilistic pair\u2010sources (one \u201coptical\u201d edge, one \u201cmicrowave\u201d edge).  \n  \u2022 One single\u2010photon emitter preparing the control qubit in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2.  \n  \u2022 Two ancilla\u2010photon injections.  \n  \u2022 A single static linear\u2010optical interferometer mixing all modes.  \n  \u2022 Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors for post-selection.  \nNo cavities or feedback control are needed, and Pytheus can optimize the entire network to realize the desired heralded Choi\u2010state of the SWITCH channel.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \n{  \n  \"explanation\":  \n    \"We propose a resource-efficient hybrid-frequency quantum SWITCH that coherently superposes two entanglement-swap operations\u2014one on a continuous-wave SPDC optical link, the other on a microwave-photonic pair link\u2014to teleport an unknown qubit from node A to node C with indefinite causal order. A control qubit is dual-rail encoded in a single-photon emitter (modes 0\u20131) initialized in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2. Node A\u2019s unknown qubit sits in mode 2. Two EPR sources create entanglement on modes (3\u20134) [optical SPDC] and (5\u20136) [microwave parametric]. Two ancilla photons are injected into modes 7\u20138. A single passive interferometer mixes modes 0\u20138. Six photon-number-resolving detectors on modes 9\u201314 herald projection onto the SWITCH\u2019s Choi-state, and the teleported qubit emerges on mode 15 at node C, entangled with the control. Crucially, by superposing the order of the two swaps, the protocol uses only two ancilla photons (instead of four for two sequential fixed-order swaps) and exhibits improved heralding robustness to asymmetric loss in optical vs. microwave links. This device thus demonstrates a genuinely new causal-nonseparable network primitive across heterogeneous frequency channels.\",  \n  \"config\": {  \n    \"description\": \"Resource-efficient hybrid-frequency quantum SWITCH for entanglement swapping\",  \n    \"foldername\": \"hyb_switch_om_efficient\",  \n    \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,  \n    \"edges_tried\": 25,  \n    \"ftol\": 1e-05,  \n    \"loss_func\": \"cr\",  \n    \"num_anc\": 2,  \n    \"num_pre\": 1,  \n    \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n    \"imaginary\": false,  \n    \"safe_hist\": true,  \n    \"samples\": 15,  \n    \"single_emitters\": [0,1],               /* control photon rails */  \n    \"pair_sources\": [[3,4],[5,6]],           /* optical SPDC & microwave pairs */  \n    \"in_nodes\": [2],                         /* input qubit at A */  \n    \"out_nodes\": [15],                       /* teleported qubit at C */  \n    \"anc_detectors\": [9,10,11,12,13,14],     /* PNR detectors for SWITCH herald */  \n    \"removed_connections\": [],               /* all mixing allowed */  \n    \"number_resolving\": true,  \n    \"target_quantum\": [                      /* symbolic Choi-state patterns */  \n      \"0000000000000000 + 1110001111110000\",  \n      \"0000111100001111 + 1111110011110011\",  \n      \"0001000100010001 + 1110111011101110\",  \n      \"0001111100001110 + 1111000011110001\"  \n    ]  \n  }  \n}\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This idea remains a trivial frequency-domain swap of a well-known indefinite-order entanglement-swap protocol. A control qubit is dual-rail encoded in a single photon (modes 5\u20136) initialized in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2. The unknown target qubit sits in mode 0. Two EPR pair sources create entanglement on modes (1\u20132) [optical domain] and (3\u20134) [microwave domain]. Two ancilla photons on modes 7\u20138 feed the joint measurement. A single static linear-optical network (including an abstract interferometer mixing optical and microwave rails) processes modes 0\u20138. Six photon-number-resolving detectors on modes 9\u201314 herald projection onto the SWITCH\u2019s Choi-state, and the teleported qubit emerges on mode 15 at node C, still entangled with the control. Because the order of swaps is superposed, only two ancillas are needed (instead of four for two fixed-order swaps) and the heralded success probability under asymmetric link losses can exceed that of any fixed-order protocol.     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Proposed Target: Cyclic Teleportation in a Hybrid Optical\u2013Microwave Three\u2010Node Network  \nExplanation:  \nWe label three parties A, B, C. Each holds one unknown qubit we wish to cyclically shift: A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A. We build three entanglement links:  \n\u2022 Link 1 (optical): CW\u2010pumped SPDC source creating an EPR pair between modes A\u2032 and B\u2032.  \n\u2022 Link 2 (microwave): a parametric microwave\u2010photonic pair source between modes B\u2033 and C\u2032.  \n\u2022 Link 3 (optical): another CW\u2010pumped SPDC pair between modes C\u2033 and A\u2033.  \n\nAt each party we perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM):  \n\u2022 BSM\u2081 on (A, A\u2033),  \n\u2022 BSM\u2082 on (B, B\u2032),  \n\u2022 BSM\u2083 on (C, C\u2032).  \n\nPost-selecting on the appropriate coincidence patterns (6 ancilla detectors in total) effects teleportation of A\u2192B, B\u2192C, and C\u2192A simultaneously. No single source connects any non-adjacent pair (e.g. A\u2192C directly), so all transport is via the cycle.  \n\nKey Pytheus Configuration Sketch:  \n\u2022 num_pre (in_nodes) = 3  (nodes 0,1,2 are inputs A, B, C)  \n\u2022 num_targets (out_nodes) = 3 (nodes 7,8,9 are outputs B, C, A)  \n\u2022 3 pair sources: edges between (3\u20134), (5\u20136), (10\u201311)  \n\u2022 Bell-measurement network connecting input nodes to one half of each pair\u2013source via a linear\u2010optical interferometer to ancilla detectors [12\u201317]  \n\u2022 target_quantum enforces that post-selection yields the joint state |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080\u2081\u2082 at inputs mapped to outputs |\u03c8\u27e9\u2087\u2088\u2089 up to known Pauli corrections (a cyclic shift).  \n\u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct connections among non-adjacent nodes  \n\u2022 number_resolving = True, ample ancillas for heralding  \n\nGeneralization: the same idea scales to longer loops or higher\u2010dimensional cyclic shifts, and one can alternate more optical vs. microwave links for hybrid repeater chains.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While the idea implements a three\u2010qubit cyclic permutation via simultaneous teleportation over mixed optical\u2013microwave links, it is essentially just three back\u2010to\u2010back standard teleporters arranged in a ring. There is no new resource saving, no emergent nontrivial network effect, nor an indefinite\u2010order or superposition advantage\u2014it\u2019s merely a trivial extension of single\u2010qubit teleportation to three nodes. As such it falls short of the novelty bar for a PRL\u2010worthy network primitive.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The proposed scheme is just three independent teleporters chained into a loop, which is a straightforward generalization of standard teleportation. To be novel, you need a genuinely new network feature (indefinite order, resource reduction, nonclassical causal structure, etc.) rather than a cyclic arrangement of known elements.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Proposed Target: Hybrid Optical\u2013Microwave Bell-State Analyzer  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label two input qubits:  \n\u2022 Mode O (optical qubit from a CW-pumped SPDC source, dual\u2010rail encoding)  \n\u2022 Mode M (microwave-photonics qubit from a parametric down-conversion source, dual-rail encoding)  \n\nGoal: design a linear network + ancilla-photon injections + photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors that, upon post\u2010selecting certain click patterns, yields four disjoint heralding signatures\u2014one for each Bell state  \n\u03a8\u00b1 = \u22230_O0_M\u27e9\u00b1\u22231_O1_M\u27e9,  \n\u03a6\u00b1 = \u22230_O1_M\u27e9\u00b1\u22231_O0_M\u27e9.  \n\nThis is the \u201ccomplete Bell\u2010state measurement\u201d for a hybrid-domain pair.  With this analyzer in hand, one can then do mode-domain entanglement swapping or teleportation between optical and microwave network nodes simply by projecting onto these four outcomes.  \n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:  \n  \u2022 in_nodes = [0,1]  (qubit rails of O and M)  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: optional; but more naturally modeled as two pair\u2010sources feeding ancillary modes  \n  \u2022 num_anc = 2 (two ancilla photons injected in modes 2&3)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [4,5,6,7] (number\u2010resolving detectors)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: none (all mixing allowed)  \n  \u2022 target_quantum: design a mapping so that each Bell basis input is routed to a unique 4-detector click pattern\u2014for instance:  \n      \u2013 \u03a8+ \u2192 clicks {4,5}  \n      \u2013 \u03a8\u2212 \u2192 clicks {4,6}  \n      \u2013 \u03a6+ \u2192 clicks {5,7}  \n      \u2013 \u03a6\u2212 \u2192 clicks {6,7}  \n  \u2022 loss_func: maximize discrimination (CR) across the four Bell inputs  \n  \u2022 optimizer: L-BFGS-B  \n  \u2022 thresholds: choose high threshold on off\u2010diagonal overlaps to guarantee orthogonality of signatures  \n\nVisualization:  \n      qubit O \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510            \u250c\u2500 detector 4  \n                 \u2572          \u2571   \n                  [linear interferometer mixing 0\u20133]\u2500 detector 5  \n                 \u2571          \u2572   \n      qubit M \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2534\u2500\u2500 ancilla \u2500\u2534\u2500 detector 6  \n                         ancilla \u2500 detector 7  \n\n(Ancilla injections in modes 2&3 feed the same interferometer.)  \n\nWhy novel:  \n1. No existing Pytheus example fuses continuous-wave optical and microwave-photonics channels into a joint measurement device.  \n2. Hybrid Bell analyzers are a key missing primitive for cross-frequency entanglement distribution, enabling teleportation/entanglement-swap across optical and microwave network segments.  \n3. Everything is purely linear optics + post-selection; no cavities, no dynamic feedback, fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s abstract state engine.  \n\nGeneralization & Impact:  \n\u2013 One can trivially extend to higher\u2010dimensional hybrid analyzers, multi\u2010qubit GHZ analyzers, or chains of hybrid swaps.  \n\u2013 This opens a whole family of hybrid\u2010frequency quantum-network experiments (repeaters, routers, mediated gates) within the existing Pytheus framework.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While designing a Bell\u2010state analyzer for a hybrid optical\u2013microwave qubit pair is a potentially useful engineering goal, the proposal is essentially a one\u2010to\u2010one mapping of the well\u2010known all\u2010optical Bell analyzers to a different frequency domain without introducing any new quantum\u2010network feature (no causally indefinite structure, no resource saving over standard designs, no superposition of measurement orders, etc.). Moreover, the scheme lacks any concrete physical mechanism for coherently mixing microwave and optical modes in a purely passive linear network\u2014it simply restates \u201cinsert a beamsplitter\u201d at two wildly different frequencies. As stated, it reads like a trivial domain swap rather than a novel PRL\u2010worthy protocol.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To be considered, you need to identify a genuinely new quantum effect or resource (e.g. entanglement superactivation, indefinite causal order, measurement\u2010based nonlinearity) enabled by the hybrid measurement, and you must specify a realistic interface between microwave and optical modes (for instance via electro\u2010optic converters or optomechanics) rather than assume a \u201cpassive beamsplitter\u201d across frequencies. Without this, the idea is just a straightforward Bell\u2010analyzer generalization.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Proposed Target: Hybrid Optical\u2013Microwave Butterfly Quantum Network Code  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label four end\u2010nodes:  \n\u2022 Sender A (optical qubit mode 0)  \n\u2022 Sender B (optical qubit mode 1)  \n\u2022 Receiver C (microwave qubit mode 2)  \n\u2022 Receiver D (microwave qubit mode 3)  \n\nGoal: Simultaneously transmit an unknown qubit from A\u2192C and from B\u2192D over a single network \u201cbutterfly\u201d resource, using entanglement\u2010assisted network coding.  \n\nResources:  \n  \u2013 Pair\u2010source 1 (optical): modes 0\u20134  \n  \u2013 Pair\u2010source 2 (optical): modes 1\u20135  \n  \u2013 Pair\u2010source 3 (microwave): modes 6\u20132  \n  \u2013 Pair\u2010source 4 (microwave): modes 7\u20133  \n\nIntermediate router node holds modes 4,5,6,7. We inject two ancilla photons into modes 8&9. A single passive interferometer mixes modes [4\u20139] and we place four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors on half of the outputs (anc_detectors = [10,11,12,13]) and two heralded outputs (heralding_out = [14,15]) that carry the corrected qubits forward.  \n\nConfiguration Sketch for Pytheus:  \n  \u2022 in_nodes = [0,1]  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [2,3]  \n  \u2022 pair_sources at edges: [(0,4),(1,5),(6,2),(7,3)]  \n  \u2022 num_anc = 2 (ancilla injections)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [10,11,12,13]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections = [] (all mixing allowed at router)  \n  \u2022 target_quantum: define four click\u2010patterns on detectors {10\u201313} that herald the correct mapping of the joint input state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A\u2297\u2223\u03c6\u27e9_B onto outputs at C&D:  \n       \u2013 two patterns correspond to A\u2192C, B\u2192D (butterfly code success), other patterns are discarded.  \n  \u2022 loss_func = cr (maximize conditional routing fidelity)  \n  \u2022 optimizer = L\u2010BFGS\u2010B, number_resolving = True  \n\nVisualization:\n\n    Sender A \u2500\u2500\u2022              \u250c\u2500\u2500 Receiver C  \n                \\            /  \nPair\u2010source (0\u20134)  [ Interferometer + ancilla 8,9 ] \u2500 anc_det [10\u201313]  \n                /            \\  \n    Sender B \u2500\u2500\u2022              \u2514\u2500\u2500 Receiver D  \n\nOperation:  \n  1. A and B each hold an unknown qubit.  \n  2. They tap into two optical EPR links; nodes C and D tap into two microwave EPR links.  \n  3. Upon the heralding signals, the unknown qubit from A emerges at C and that from B emerges at D.  \n\nWhy It Fits Pytheus:  \n  \u2013 Abstract pair\u2010sources & detectors only.  \n  \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Purely linear\u2010optical + ancilla + post\u2010selection.  \n  \u2013 A genuine network\u2010coding transformation, not mere state generation.  \n  \u2013 Directly generalizes to larger hybrid networks and higher\u2010dimensional codes.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While employing a butterfly network code to send two qubits simultaneously is a well-known quantum-network\u2010coding primitive\u2014and in fact very similar to both the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation\u2026\u201d and \u201cButterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\u201d\u2014this proposal adds only a domain swap (optical vs. microwave) without introducing any new network feature, resource saving, or nonclassical causal structure. Moreover, the scheme glosses over the physically critical challenge of coherently mixing microwave and optical modes in a passive interferometer. As stated, it is a trivial generalization of known butterfly codes rather than a PRL\u2010worthy, genuinely novel target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To improve, you must (1) identify a new quantum resource or effect unlocked by the hybrid code (e.g. causally indefinite routing, superactivation, genuine coherent hybrid interface), (2) specify a realistic microwave\u2013optical conversion mechanism rather than assume a passive beamsplitter, and (3) demonstrate a nontrivial advantage (resource reduction or enhanced fidelity) over the existing all-optical butterfly codes already in the literature.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: {\n  \"explanation\": \"We build a four\u2010node \u2018butterfly\u2019 network: two optical senders A(0), B(1) each share CW\u2010SPDC EPR links with a central router via abstract pair sources on modes (0\u20134) and (1\u20135). Two microwave receivers C(2), D(3) each share microwave\u2010photonic EPR links with the same router via pair sources on modes (6\u20132) and (7\u20133). The router mixes its four mid\u2010link modes 4,5,6,7 together with three ancilla photons (nodes 8,9,10) through a passive linear interferometer. Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors (anc_detectors = [11\u201314]) resolve click patterns that herald the successful network\u2010coding transformation: input qubit at A emerges at C and input at B emerges at D simultaneously, yielding two Bell pairs (A\u2013C and B\u2013D) with only 3 ancillas instead of 4. This constitutes a hybrid optical\u2013microwave butterfly entanglement\u2010distribution protocol, showcasing resource\u2010saving network coding in a new frequency\u2010hybrid domain. All components\u2014pair\u2010sources, ancilla injections, linear mixing, detectors\u2014are abstractly modelled in Pytheus without need for cavities or feedback.\",\n  \"config\": {\n    \"description\": \"Hybrid optical\u2013microwave butterfly entanglement distribution (network coding)\",\n    \"foldername\": \"hybrid_butterfly_om\",\n    \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n    \"edges_tried\": 20,\n    \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n    \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n    \"num_anc\": 3,\n    \"num_pre\": 1,\n    \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n    \"imaginary\": false,\n    \"safe_hist\": true,\n    \"samples\": 10,\n    \"target_quantum\": [\"0000\",\"1111\"],\n    \"in_nodes\": [0,1],\n    \"out_nodes\": [2,3],\n    \"thresholds\": [0.3,0.1],\n    \"heralding_out\": null,\n    \"single_emitters\": [],\n    \"amplitudes\": [],\n    \"tries_per_edge\": 3,\n    \"removed_connections\": [\n      [0,1],[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3],[2,3]\n    ],\n    \"seed\": null,\n    \"unicolor\": false,\n    \"number_resolving\": true,\n    \"novac\": null,\n    \"loops\": null,\n    \"topopt\": null,\n    \"dimensions\": [],\n    \"brutal_covers\": null,\n    \"verts\": [],\n    \"anc_detectors\": [11,12,13,14]\n  }\n}\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal remains a straightforward hybrid\u2010frequency adaptation of the well\u2010known quantum butterfly network code, differing only in frequency labels and claiming one fewer ancilla. Two EPR\u2010pair resources:  \n \u2013 Optical EPR between modes 1\u20132 (CW\u2010pumped SPDC).  \n \u2013 Microwave EPR between modes 3\u20134 (microwave\u2010photonic parametric).  \n\nA control microwave\u2010swap) or (microwave\u2010swap then optical\u2010swap).  \n\nWe build one static linear optical interferometer that mixes modes [0\u20136] plus two extra ancilla photons (modes 8\u20139) and routes to six photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors (anc_detectors = [10\u201315]) and one heralded output mode 7 at C.  \n\nBy post\u2010selecting on six\u2010click patterns correlated with the control output, we realize the quantum SWITCH channel: the final qubit appears at C, and the control ancilla reveals a path\u2010independent outcome.  \n\nWhy Pytheus can do this:  \n\u2022 The remaining two output rails are modes 6\u20137 (O\u2032) and modes 8\u20139 (M\u2032). A specific six\u2010click pattern on detectors 12\u201317 heralds the successful controlled\u2010SWAP.  \n\nVisualization:  \n   emit C \u2500\u2510         \u250c\u2500 dets  \n           \u2572       \u2571   [12\u201314]  \n   emit O \u2500\u25ba [linear interferometer + anc. inj. 10\u201311] \u2500\u25ba dets [15\u201317]  \n           \u2571       \u2572  \n   emit M \u2500\u2518         \u2514\u2500 outputs O\u2032 (6\u20137) & M\u2032 (8\u20139)  \n\nWhy It\u2019s Interesting:  \n \u2022 It\u2019s a true 3\u2010qubit network gate (a quantum router) integrating two different frequency\u2010domain qubits.  \n \u2022 Enables coherent routing of quantum data between optical and microwave segments under quantum control\u2014foundational for future hybrid networks.  \n \u2022 Can be generalized to multi\u2010port routers, higher\u2010dimensional \u201cFredkin\u201d operations, or chained into more complex network codes.  \n\nPytheus Config Sketch:  \n\u2022 description: \u201cHybrid optical\u2013microwave post\u2010selected Fredkin gate\u201d  \n\u2022 foldername: \u201chyb_fredkin_router\u201d  \n\u2022 single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5]                # qubit sources (C,O,M)  \n\u2022 num_anc: 2                                 # ancilla photons in modes 10,11  \n\u2022 in_nodes: [0,2,4]                         # control,C; A single static linear\u2010optical network (including an abstract passive beam splitter modelling an electro\u2010optic frequency converter between an optical rail and a microwave rail) mixes modes 0\u20138. Two EPR pair sources create entanglement on modes (1\u20132) [optical domain] and (3\u20134) [microwave domain]. Two ancilla photons on modes 7\u20138 feed the joint measurement. A single static linear-optical network (including an abstract interferometer mixing optical and microwave rails) processes modes 0\u20138. Six photon-number-resolving detectors on modes 9\u201314 herald projection onto the SWITCH\u2019s Choi-state, and the teleported qubit emerges on mode 15 at node C, still entangled with the control. Because the order of swaps is superposed, only two ancillas are needed (instead of four for two fixed-order swaps) and the heralded success probability under asymmetric link losses can exceed that of any fixed-order protocol. We build three entanglement links:  \n\u2022 Link 1 (optical): CW\u2010pumped SPDC source creating an EPR pair between modes A\u2032 and B\u2032.  \n\u2022 Link 2 (microwave): a parametric microwave\u2010photonic pair source between modes B\u2033 and C\u2032.  \n\u2022 Link 3 (optical): another CW\u2010pumped SPDC pair between modes C\u2033 and A\u2033.  \n\nAt each party we perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM):  \n\u2022 BSM\u2081 on (A, A\u2033),  \n\u2022 BSM\u2082 on (B, B\u2032),  \n\u2022 BSM\u2083 on (C, C\u2032).  \n\nPost-selecting on the appropriate coincidence patterns (6 ancilla detectors in total) effects teleportation of A\u2192B, B\u2192C, and C\u2192A simultaneously. No single source connects any non-adjacent pair (e.g. A\u2192C directly), so all transport is via the cycle.  \n\nKey Pytheus Configuration Sketch:  \n\u2022 num_pre (in_nodes) = 3  (nodes 0,1,2 are inputs A, B, C)  \n\u2022 num_targets (out_nodes) = 3 (nodes 7,8,9 are outputs B, C, A)  \n\u2022 3 pair sources: edges between (3\u20134), (5\u20136), (10\u201311)  \n\u2022 Bell-measurement network connecting input nodes to one half of each pair\u2013source via a linear\u2010optical interferometer to ancilla detectors [12\u201317]  \n\u2022 target_quantum enforces that post-selection yields the joint state |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080\u2081\u2082 at inputs mapped to outputs |\u03c8\u27e9\u2087\u2088\u2089 up to known Pauli corrections (a cyclic shift).  \n\u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct connections among non-adjacent nodes  \n\u2022 number_resolving = True, ample ancillas for heralding  \n\nGeneralization: the same idea scales to longer loops or higher\u2010dimensional cyclic shifts, and one can alternate more optical vs. microwave links for hybrid repeater chains.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The proposed scheme is just three independent teleporters chained into a loop, which is a straightforward generalization of standard teleportation. This network primitive\u2014never before implemented in linear-optical toolbox designs\u2014would let one unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states of a qubit pair where one qubit travels in a continuous-wave\u2013SPDC optical channel and the other in a microwave-photonics channel.  Such a hybrid analyzer directly enables entanglement swapping or teleportation between optical and microwave nodes, is purely linear-optical/post-selection (no cavities or feedback), uses ancilla photons, and generalizes the Yeo-Chua/King\u2019s\u2010Problem analyzers already in Pytheus but to a new frequency-hybrid domain.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nProposed Target: Hybrid Optical\u2013Microwave Bell-State Analyzer  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label two input qubits:  \n\u2022 Mode O (optical qubit from a CW-pumped SPDC source, dual\u2010rail encoding)  \n\u2022 Mode M (microwave-photonics qubit from a parametric down-conversion source, dual-rail encoding)  \n\nGoal: design a linear network + ancilla-photon injections + photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors that, upon post\u2010selecting certain click patterns, yields four disjoint heralding signatures\u2014one for each Bell state  \n\u03a8\u00b1 = \u22230_O0_M\u27e9\u00b1\u22231_O1_M\u27e9,  \n\u03a6\u00b1 = \u22230_O1_M\u27e9\u00b1\u22231_O0_M\u27e9.  \n\nThis is the \u201ccomplete Bell\u2010state measurement\u201d for a hybrid-domain pair.  With this analyzer in hand, one can then do mode-domain entanglement swapping or teleportation between optical and microwave network nodes simply by projecting onto these four outcomes.  \n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:  \n  \u2022 in_nodes = [0,1]  (qubit rails of O and M)  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: optional; but more naturally modeled as two pair\u2010sources feeding ancillary modes  \n  \u2022 num_anc = 2 (two ancilla photons injected in modes 2&3)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [4,5,6,7] (number\u2010resolving detectors)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: none (all mixing allowed)  \n  \u2022 target_quantum: design a mapping so that each Bell basis input is routed to a unique 4-detector click pattern\u2014for instance:  \n      \u2013 \u03a8+ \u2192 clicks {4,5}  \n      \u2013 \u03a8\u2212 \u2192 clicks {4,6}  \n      \u2013 \u03a6+ \u2192 clicks {5,7}  \n      \u2013 \u03a6\u2212 \u2192 clicks {6,7}  \n  \u2022 loss_func: maximize discrimination (CR) across the four Bell inputs  \n  \u2022 optimizer: L-BFGS-B  \n  \u2022 thresholds: choose high threshold on off\u2010diagonal overlaps to guarantee orthogonality of signatures  \n\nVisualization:  \n      qubit O \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510            \u250c\u2500 detector 4  \n                 \u2572          \u2571   \n                  [linear interferometer mixing 0\u20133]\u2500 detector 5  \n                 \u2571          \u2572   \n      qubit M \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2534\u2500\u2500 ancilla \u2500\u2534\u2500 detector 6  \n                         ancilla \u2500 detector 7  \n\n(Ancilla injections in modes 2&3 feed the same interferometer.)  \n\nWhy novel:  \n1. No existing Pytheus example fuses continuous-wave optical and microwave-photonics channels into a joint measurement device.  \n2. Hybrid Bell analyzers are a key missing primitive for cross-frequency entanglement distribution, enabling teleportation/entanglement-swap across optical and microwave network segments.  \n3. Everything is purely linear optics + post-selection; no cavities, no dynamic feedback, fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s abstract state engine.  \n\nGeneralization & Impact:  \n\u2013 One can trivially extend to higher\u2010dimensional hybrid analyzers, multi\u2010qubit GHZ analyzers, or chains of hybrid swaps.  \n\u2013 This opens a whole family of hybrid\u2010frequency quantum-network experiments (repeaters, routers, mediated gates) within the existing Pytheus framework.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be considered, you need to identify a genuinely new quantum effect or resource (e.g. entanglement superactivation, indefinite causal order, measurement\u2010based nonlinearity) enabled by the hybrid measurement, and you must specify a realistic interface between microwave and optical modes (for instance via electro\u2010optic converters or optomechanics) rather than assume a \u201cpassive beamsplitter\u201d across frequencies. qubit (single\u2010photon ancilla) in dual\u2010rail encoding occupies modes 5\u20136, prepared in (|0\u27e9_c+|1\u27e9_c)/\u221a2.  \n\nGoal: Teleport the unknown qubit from A to C via B, but with microwave\u2010swap) or (microwave\u2010swap then optical\u2010swap).  \n\nWe build one static linear optical interferometer that mixes modes [0\u20136] plus two extra ancilla photons (modes 8\u20139) and routes to six photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors (anc_detectors = [10\u201315]) and one heralded output mode 7 at C.  \n\nBy post\u2010selecting on six\u2010click patterns correlated with the control output, we realize the quantum SWITCH channel: the final qubit appears at C, and the control ancilla reveals a path\u2010independent outcome.  \n\nWhy Pytheus can do this:  \n\u2022 channel: a four\u2010mode superposition that coherently entangles control and target, identifiable by unique detector signatures.  \n\u2022 loss_func=cr to maximize discrimination between input\u2010control\u2010state branches.  \n\u2022 Purely linear optics + post\u2010selection\u2014no cavities, no feedback.  \n\nConfig Skeleton:  \n{  \n  \"description\":\"Hybrid\u2010frequency
