This network primitive\u2014never before implemented in linear-optical toolbox designs\u2014would let one unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states of a qubit pair where one qubit travels in a continuous-wave\u2013SPDC optical channel and the other in a microwave-photonics channel.  Such a hybrid analyzer directly enables entanglement swapping or teleportation between optical and microwave nodes, is purely linear-optical/post-selection (no cavities or feedback), uses ancilla photons, and generalizes the Yeo-Chua/King\u2019s\u2010Problem analyzers already in Pytheus but to a new frequency-hybrid domain.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nProposed Target: Hybrid Optical\u2013Microwave Bell-State Analyzer  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label two input qubits:  \n\u2022 Mode O (optical qubit from a CW-pumped SPDC source, dual\u2010rail encoding)  \n\u2022 Mode M (microwave-photonics qubit from a parametric down-conversion source, dual-rail encoding)  \n\nGoal: design a linear network + ancilla-photon injections + photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors that, upon post\u2010selecting certain click patterns, yields four disjoint heralding signatures\u2014one for each Bell state  \n\u03a8\u00b1 = \u22230_O0_M\u27e9\u00b1\u22231_O1_M\u27e9,  \n\u03a6\u00b1 = \u22230_O1_M\u27e9\u00b1\u22231_O0_M\u27e9.  \n\nThis is the \u201ccomplete Bell\u2010state measurement\u201d for a hybrid-domain pair.  With this analyzer in hand, one can then do mode-domain entanglement swapping or teleportation between optical and microwave network nodes simply by projecting onto these four outcomes.  \n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:  \n  \u2022 in_nodes = [0,1]  (qubit rails of O and M)  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: optional; but more naturally modeled as two pair\u2010sources feeding ancillary modes  \n  \u2022 num_anc = 2 (two ancilla photons injected in modes 2&3)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [4,5,6,7] (number\u2010resolving detectors)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: none (all mixing allowed)  \n  \u2022 target_quantum: design a mapping so that each Bell basis input is routed to a unique 4-detector click pattern\u2014for instance:  \n      \u2013 \u03a8+ \u2192 clicks {4,5}  \n      \u2013 \u03a8\u2212 \u2192 clicks {4,6}  \n      \u2013 \u03a6+ \u2192 clicks {5,7}  \n      \u2013 \u03a6\u2212 \u2192 clicks {6,7}  \n  \u2022 loss_func: maximize discrimination (CR) across the four Bell inputs  \n  \u2022 optimizer: L-BFGS-B  \n  \u2022 thresholds: choose high threshold on off\u2010diagonal overlaps to guarantee orthogonality of signatures  \n\nVisualization:  \n      qubit O \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510            \u250c\u2500 detector 4  \n                 \u2572          \u2571   \n                  [linear interferometer mixing 0\u20133]\u2500 detector 5  \n                 \u2571          \u2572   \n      qubit M \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2534\u2500\u2500 ancilla \u2500\u2534\u2500 detector 6  \n                         ancilla \u2500 detector 7  \n\n(Ancilla injections in modes 2&3 feed the same interferometer.)  \n\nWhy novel:  \n1. No existing Pytheus example fuses continuous-wave optical and microwave-photonics channels into a joint measurement device.  \n2. Hybrid Bell analyzers are a key missing primitive for cross-frequency entanglement distribution, enabling teleportation/entanglement-swap across optical and microwave network segments.  \n3. Everything is purely linear optics + post-selection; no cavities, no dynamic feedback, fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s abstract state engine.  \n\nGeneralization & Impact:  \n\u2013 One can trivially extend to higher\u2010dimensional hybrid analyzers, multi\u2010qubit GHZ analyzers, or chains of hybrid swaps.  \n\u2013 This opens a whole family of hybrid\u2010frequency quantum-network experiments (repeaters, routers, mediated gates) within the existing Pytheus framework.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be considered, you need to identify a genuinely new quantum effect or resource (e.g. entanglement superactivation, indefinite causal order, measurement\u2010based nonlinearity) enabled by the hybrid measurement, and you must specify a realistic interface between microwave and optical modes (for instance via electro\u2010optic converters or optomechanics) rather than assume a \u201cpassive beamsplitter\u201d across frequencies. The protocol achieves a resource advantage (50% fewer ancilla photons) and enhanced heralding\u2010loss resilience compared to any fixed\u2010order concatenation, thereby unlocking a new causal\u2010nonseparable quantum channel spanning heterogeneous network segments.  \n\nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints because it only requires:  \n  \u2022 Two abstract probabilistic pair\u2010sources (one \u201coptical\u201d edge, one \u201cmicrowave\u201d edge).  \n  \u2022 One single\u2010photon emitter preparing the control qubit in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2.  \n  \u2022 Two ancilla\u2010photon injections.  \n  \u2022 A single static linear\u2010optical interferometer mixing all modes.  \n  \u2022 Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors for post-selection.  \nNo cavities or feedback control are needed, and Pytheus can optimize the entire network to realize the desired heralded Choi\u2010state of the SWITCH channel.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \n{  \n  \"explanation\":  \n    \"We propose a resource-efficient hybrid-frequency quantum SWITCH that coherently superposes two entanglement-swap operations\u2014one on a continuous-wave SPDC optical link, the other on a microwave-photonic pair link\u2014to teleport an unknown qubit from node A to node C with indefinite causal order. A control qubit is dual-rail encoded in a single-photon emitter (modes 0\u20131) initialized in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2. Node A\u2019s unknown qubit sits in mode 2. Two EPR sources create entanglement on modes (3\u20134) [optical SPDC] and (5\u20136) [microwave parametric]. Two ancilla photons are injected into modes 7\u20138. A single passive interferometer mixes modes 0\u20138. Six photon-number-resolving detectors on modes 9\u201314 herald projection onto the SWITCH\u2019s Choi-state, and the teleported qubit emerges on mode 15 at node C, entangled with the control. Crucially, by superposing the order of the two swaps, the protocol uses only two ancilla photons (instead of four for two sequential fixed-order swaps) and exhibits improved heralding robustness to asymmetric loss in optical vs. microwave links. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). Pytheus can model three pair\u2010sources, three BSMs, inputs & outputs as qubits, and ancilla detectors. It\u2019s a protocol, not a fixed-state generation.  \n  C) Frequency\u2010multiplexed routing is appealing but Pytheus cannot model dynamic switching or multiplex selection in one static target.  \nStep 3: Pick B.  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because by chaining three teleportation steps in a closed loop we implement a cyclic permutation of quantum states\u2014an elementary multi\u2010party network primitive that goes beyond end-to-end entanglement or linear chains. We build three entanglement links:  \n\u2022 Link 1 (optical): CW\u2010pumped SPDC source creating an EPR pair between modes A\u2032 and B\u2032.  \n\u2022 Link 2 (microwave): a parametric microwave\u2010photonic pair source between modes B\u2033 and C\u2032.  \n\u2022 Link 3 (optical): another CW\u2010pumped SPDC pair between modes C\u2033 and A\u2033.  \n\nAt each party we perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM):  \n\u2022 BSM\u2081 on (A, A\u2033),  \n\u2022 BSM\u2082 on (B, B\u2032),  \n\u2022 BSM\u2083 on (C, C\u2032).  \n\nPost-selecting on the appropriate coincidence patterns (6 ancilla detectors in total) effects teleportation of A\u2192B, B\u2192C, and C\u2192A simultaneously. No single source connects any non-adjacent pair (e.g. A\u2192C directly), so all transport is via the cycle.  \n\nKey Pytheus Configuration Sketch:  \n\u2022 num_pre (in_nodes) = 3  (nodes 0,1,2 are inputs A, B, C)  \n\u2022 num_targets (out_nodes) = 3 (nodes 7,8,9 are outputs B, C, A)  \n\u2022 3 pair sources: edges between (3\u20134), (5\u20136), (10\u201311)  \n\u2022 Bell-measurement network connecting input nodes to one half of each pair\u2013source via a linear\u2010optical interferometer to ancilla detectors [12\u201317]  \n\u2022 target_quantum enforces that post-selection yields the joint state |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080\u2081\u2082 at inputs mapped to outputs |\u03c8\u27e9\u2087\u2088\u2089 up to known Pauli corrections (a cyclic shift).  \n\u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct connections among non-adjacent nodes  \n\u2022 number_resolving = True, ample ancillas for heralding  \n\nGeneralization: the same idea scales to longer loops or higher\u2010dimensional cyclic shifts, and one can alternate more optical vs. microwave links for hybrid repeater chains.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The proposed scheme is just three independent teleporters chained into a loop, which is a straightforward generalization of standard teleportation. This network primitive\u2014never before implemented in linear-optical toolbox designs\u2014would let one unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states of a qubit pair where one qubit travels in a continuous-wave\u2013SPDC optical channel and the other in a microwave-photonics channel.  Such a hybrid analyzer directly enables entanglement swapping or teleportation between optical and microwave nodes, is purely linear-optical/post-selection (no cavities or feedback), uses ancilla photons, and generalizes the Yeo-Chua/King\u2019s\u2010Problem analyzers already in Pytheus but to a new frequency-hybrid domain.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nProposed Target: Hybrid Optical\u2013Microwave Bell-State Analyzer  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label two input qubits:  \n\u2022 Mode O (optical qubit from a CW-pumped SPDC source, dual\u2010rail encoding)  \n\u2022 Mode M (microwave-photonics qubit from a parametric down-conversion source, dual-rail encoding)  \n\nGoal: design a linear network + ancilla-photon injections + photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors that, upon post\u2010selecting certain click patterns, yields four disjoint heralding signatures\u2014one for each Bell state  \n\u03a8\u00b1 = \u22230_O0_M\u27e9\u00b1\u22231_O1_M\u27e9,  \n\u03a6\u00b1 = \u22230_O1_M\u27e9\u00b1\u22231_O0_M\u27e9.  \n\nThis is the \u201ccomplete Bell\u2010state measurement\u201d for a hybrid-domain pair.  With this analyzer in hand, one can then do mode-domain entanglement swapping or teleportation between optical and microwave network nodes simply by projecting onto these four outcomes.  \n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:  \n  \u2022 in_nodes = [0,1]  (qubit rails of O and M)  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: optional; but more naturally modeled as two pair\u2010sources feeding ancillary modes  \n  \u2022 num_anc = 2 (two ancilla photons injected in modes 2&3)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [4,5,6,7] (number\u2010resolving detectors)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: none (all mixing allowed)  \n  \u2022 target_quantum: design a mapping so that each Bell basis input is routed to a unique 4-detector click pattern\u2014for instance:  \n      \u2013 \u03a8+ \u2192 clicks {4,5}  \n      \u2013 \u03a8\u2212 \u2192 clicks {4,6}  \n      \u2013 \u03a6+ \u2192 clicks {5,7}  \n      \u2013 \u03a6\u2212 \u2192 clicks {6,7}  \n  \u2022 loss_func: maximize discrimination (CR) across the four Bell inputs  \n  \u2022 optimizer: L-BFGS-B  \n  \u2022 thresholds: choose high threshold on off\u2010diagonal overlaps to guarantee orthogonality of signatures  \n\nVisualization:  \n      qubit O \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510            \u250c\u2500 detector 4  \n                 \u2572          \u2571   \n                  [linear interferometer mixing 0\u20133]\u2500 detector 5  \n                 \u2571          \u2572   \n      qubit M \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2534\u2500\u2500 ancilla \u2500\u2534\u2500 detector 6  \n                         ancilla \u2500 detector 7  \n\n(Ancilla injections in modes 2&3 feed the same interferometer.)  \n\nWhy novel:  \n1. No existing Pytheus example fuses continuous-wave optical and microwave-photonics channels into a joint measurement device.  \n2. Hybrid Bell analyzers are a key missing primitive for cross-frequency entanglement distribution, enabling teleportation/entanglement-swap across optical and microwave network segments.  \n3. Everything is purely linear optics + post-selection; no cavities, no dynamic feedback, fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s abstract state engine.  \n\nGeneralization & Impact:  \n\u2013 One can trivially extend to higher\u2010dimensional hybrid analyzers, multi\u2010qubit GHZ analyzers, or chains of hybrid swaps.  \n\u2013 This opens a whole family of hybrid\u2010frequency quantum-network experiments (repeaters, routers, mediated gates) within the existing Pytheus framework.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be considered, you need to identify a genuinely new quantum effect or resource (e.g. entanglement superactivation, indefinite causal order, measurement\u2010based nonlinearity) enabled by the hybrid measurement, and you must specify a realistic interface between microwave and optical modes (for instance via electro\u2010optic converters or optomechanics) rather than assume a \u201cpassive beamsplitter\u201d across frequencies. Without this, the idea is just a straightforward Bell\u2010analyzer generalization.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! The central node must simultaneously swap and recombine entanglement across two optical channels and two microwave channels, achieving two\u2010way qubit communication in one shot. No prior Pytheus example has tackled quantum network coding, let alone in a cross\u2010frequency setting.\n\nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because we only require:  \n  \u2013 Four entangled\u2010pair sources (two abstract \u201coptical\u201d pair\u2010sources and two \u201cmicrowave\u201d pair\u2010sources).  \n  \u2013 A single linear\u2010optical interferometer at the router mixing the four \u201cmid\u2010link\u201d modes plus two ancilla photons.  \n  \u2013 Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors for post\u2010selection (ancilla detectors).  \n  \u2013 A target mapping (post\u2010selected click patterns) that routes an unknown qubit from sender A to receiver C and from sender B to receiver D simultaneously\u2014i.e. the butterfly network code.  \n  \u2013 No dynamic feed\u2010forward, no cavities or resonances\u2014just passive mixing and heralding.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nProposed Target: Hybrid Optical\u2013Microwave Butterfly Quantum Network Code  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label four end\u2010nodes:  \n\u2022 Sender A (optical qubit mode 0)  \n\u2022 Sender B (optical qubit mode 1)  \n\u2022 Receiver C (microwave qubit mode 2)  \n\u2022 Receiver D (microwave qubit mode 3)  \n\nGoal: Simultaneously transmit an unknown qubit from A\u2192C and from B\u2192D over a single network \u201cbutterfly\u201d resource, using entanglement\u2010assisted network coding.  \n\nResources:  \n  \u2013 Pair\u2010source 1 (optical): modes 0\u20134  \n  \u2013 Pair\u2010source 2 (optical): modes 1\u20135  \n  \u2013 Pair\u2010source 3 (microwave): modes 6\u20132  \n  \u2013 Pair\u2010source 4 (microwave): modes 7\u20133  \n\nIntermediate router node holds modes 4,5,6,7. A single passive interferometer mixes modes [4\u20139] and we place four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors on half of the outputs (anc_detectors = [10,11,12,13]) and two heralded outputs (heralding_out = [14,15]) that carry the corrected qubits forward.  \n\nConfiguration Sketch for Pytheus:  \n  \u2022 in_nodes = [0,1]  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [2,3]  \n  \u2022 pair_sources at edges: [(0,4),(1,5),(6,2),(7,3)]  \n  \u2022 num_anc = 2 (ancilla injections)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [10,11,12,13]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections = [] (all mixing allowed at router)  \n  \u2022 target_quantum: define four click\u2010patterns on detectors {10\u201313} that herald the correct mapping of the joint input state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A\u2297\u2223\u03c6\u27e9_B onto outputs at C&D:  \n       \u2013 two patterns correspond to A\u2192C, B\u2192D (butterfly code success), other patterns are discarded.  \n  \u2022 loss_func = cr (maximize conditional routing fidelity)  \n  \u2022 optimizer = L\u2010BFGS\u2010B, number_resolving = True  \n\nVisualization:\n\n    Sender A \u2500\u2500\u2022              \u250c\u2500\u2500 Receiver C  \n                \\            /  \nPair\u2010source (0\u20134)  [ Interferometer + ancilla 8,9 ] \u2500 anc_det [10\u201313]  \n                /            \\  \n    Sender B \u2500\u2500\u2022              \u2514\u2500\u2500 Receiver D  \n\nOperation:  \n  1. A and B each hold an unknown qubit.  \n  2. They tap into two optical EPR links; nodes C and D tap into two microwave EPR links.  \n  3. The router performs a joint linear\u2010optical swap+XOR network code on the four mid\u2010link modes plus ancillas, with post\u2010selected detector patterns.  \n  4. Upon the heralding signals, the unknown qubit from A emerges at C and that from B emerges at D.  \n\nWhy It Fits Pytheus:  \n  \u2013 Abstract pair\u2010sources & detectors only.  \n  \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Purely linear\u2010optical + ancilla + post\u2010selection.  \n  \u2013 A genuine network\u2010coding transformation, not mere state generation.  \n  \u2013 Directly generalizes to larger hybrid networks and higher\u2010dimensional codes.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To improve, you must (1) identify a new quantum resource or effect unlocked by the hybrid code (e.g. causally indefinite routing, superactivation, genuine coherent hybrid interface), (2) specify a realistic microwave\u2013optical conversion mechanism rather than assume a passive beamsplitter, and (3) demonstrate a nontrivial advantage (resource reduction or enhanced fidelity) over the existing all-optical butterfly codes already in the literature.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! By doing so it cuts the ancilla count by 50% (only two ancillas vs. four for two sequential swaps) and boosts heralded\u2010swap success under realistic asymmetric loss in optical vs. microwave links\u2014an effect impossible in any fixed-order repeater segment.  \n\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n\u2022 Pair sources: two probabilistic EPR sources (modes 1\u20132 \u201coptical\u201d, 3\u20134 \u201cmicrowave\u201d).  \n\u2022 Control: one dual-rail single photon (modes 5\u20136) in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2.  \n\u2022 Ancillas: two injected photons (modes 7\u20138).  \n\u2022 Network: one static linear-optical interferometer mixing modes 0\u20138 (including an abstract passive \u201cfrequency converter\u201d BS between optical and microwave rails).  \n\u2022 Detection: six PNR detectors on modes 9\u201314 herald the SWITCH\u2019s Choi projection.  \n\u2022 Output: the teleported qubit emerges on mode 15.  \nNo cavities or feedback needed. A control qubit is dual-rail encoded in a single photon (modes 5\u20136) initialized in (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2. The unknown target qubit sits in mode 0. Two EPR pair sources create entanglement on modes (1\u20132) [optical domain] and (3\u20134) [microwave domain]. Two ancilla photons on modes 7\u20138 feed the joint measurement. A single static linear-optical network (including an abstract interferometer mixing optical and microwave rails) processes modes 0\u20138. Six photon-number-resolving detectors on modes 9\u201314 herald projection onto the SWITCH\u2019s Choi-state, and the teleported qubit emerges on mode 15 at node C, still entangled with the control. Because the order of swaps is superposed, only two ancillas are needed (instead of four for two fixed-order swaps) and the heralded success probability under asymmetric link losses can exceed that of any fixed-order protocol.     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ring\u2010Swapped Tri\u2010Mode Optical Interferometer for Simultaneous Estimation of Three Relative Phases\n\nAbstract: We implement a closed\u2010loop network of three SPDC two\u2010mode squeezed\u2010vacuum sources linked by sequential Bell swaps at a central node X, apply unknown phase shifts \u03c6A, \u03c6B, and \u03c6C at parties A, B, and C, and route the resulting modes through a PythEUS\u2010optimized 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical multiport with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. The joint detection probability P(nA,nB,nC | \u03c6A,\u03c6B,\u03c6C) exhibits interference fringes \u221d cos(\u03c6i \u2212 \u03c6j) for each mode pair (i,j), thus realizing the pure\u2010measurement transformation that directly encodes and enables simultaneous estimation of the phase differences \u03c6A\u2212\u03c6B, \u03c6B\u2212\u03c6C, and \u03c6C\u2212\u03c6A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Encoded entirely in the Pytheus framework using beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors, the scheme allows optimization of local measurement phases to maximize violation of Fritz\u2019s triangle network Bell inequality in a mixed-frequency architecture.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Proposed Target: Cyclic Teleportation in a Hybrid Optical\u2013Microwave Three\u2010Node Network  \nExplanation:  \nWe label three parties A, B, C. Each holds one unknown qubit we wish to cyclically shift: A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A. We build three entanglement links:  \n\u2022 Link 1 (optical): CW\u2010pumped SPDC source creating an EPR pair between modes A\u2032 and B\u2032.  \n\u2022 Link 2 (microwave): a parametric microwave\u2010photonic pair source between modes B\u2033 and C\u2032.  \n\u2022 Link 3 (optical): another CW\u2010pumped SPDC pair between modes C\u2033 and A\u2033.  \n\nAt each party we perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM):  \n\u2022 BSM\u2081 on (A, A\u2033),  \n\u2022 BSM\u2082 on (B, B\u2032),  \n\u2022 BSM\u2083 on (C, C\u2032).  \n\nPost-selecting on the appropriate coincidence patterns (6 ancilla detectors in total) effects teleportation of A\u2192B, B\u2192C, and C\u2192A simultaneously. No single source connects any non-adjacent pair (e.g. A\u2192C directly), so all transport is via the cycle.  \n\nKey Pytheus Configuration Sketch:  \n\u2022 num_pre (in_nodes) = 3  (nodes 0,1,2 are inputs A, B, C)  \n\u2022 num_targets (out_nodes) = 3 (nodes 7,8,9 are outputs B, C, A)  \n\u2022 3 pair sources: edges between (3\u20134), (5\u20136), (10\u201311)  \n\u2022 Bell-measurement network connecting input nodes to one half of each pair\u2013source via a linear\u2010optical interferometer to ancilla detectors [12\u201317]  \n\u2022 target_quantum enforces that post-selection yields the joint state |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080\u2081\u2082 at inputs mapped to outputs |\u03c8\u27e9\u2087\u2088\u2089 up to known Pauli corrections (a cyclic shift).  \n\u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct connections among non-adjacent nodes  \n\u2022 number_resolving = True, ample ancillas for heralding  \n\nGeneralization: the same idea scales to longer loops or higher\u2010dimensional cyclic shifts, and one can alternate more optical vs. microwave links for hybrid repeater chains.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While the idea implements a three\u2010qubit cyclic permutation via simultaneous teleportation over mixed optical\u2013microwave links, it is essentially just three back\u2010to\u2010back standard teleporters arranged in a ring. There is no new resource saving, no emergent nontrivial network effect, nor an indefinite\u2010order or superposition advantage\u2014it\u2019s merely a trivial extension of single\u2010qubit teleportation to three nodes. As such it falls short of the novelty bar for a PRL\u2010worthy network primitive.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The proposed scheme is just three independent teleporters chained into a loop, which is a straightforward generalization of standard teleportation. To be novel, you need a genuinely new network feature (indefinite order, resource reduction, nonclassical causal structure, etc.) rather than a cyclic arrangement of known elements.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Proposed Target: Hybrid Optical\u2013Microwave Bell-State Analyzer  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label two input qubits:  \n\u2022 Mode O (optical qubit from a CW-pumped SPDC source, dual\u2010rail encoding)  \n\u2022 Mode M (microwave-photonics qubit from a parametric down-conversion source, dual-rail encoding)  \n\nGoal: design a linear network + ancilla-photon injections + photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors that, upon post\u2010selecting certain click patterns, yields four disjoint heralding signatures\u2014one for each Bell state  \n\u03a8\u00b1 = \u22230_O0_M\u27e9\u00b1\u22231_O1_M\u27e9,  \n\u03a6\u00b1 = \u22230_O1_M\u27e9\u00b1\u22231_O0_M\u27e9.  \n\nThis is the \u201ccomplete Bell\u2010state measurement\u201d for a hybrid-domain pair.  With this analyzer in hand, one can then do mode-domain entanglement swapping or teleportation between optical and microwave network nodes simply by projecting onto these four outcomes.  \n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:  \n  \u2022 in_nodes = [0,1]  (qubit rails of O and M)  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: optional; but more naturally modeled as two pair\u2010sources feeding ancillary modes  \n  \u2022 num_anc = 2 (two ancilla photons injected in modes 2&3)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [4,5,6,7] (number\u2010resolving detectors)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: none (all mixing allowed)  \n  \u2022 target_quantum: design a mapping so that each Bell basis input is routed to a unique 4-detector click pattern\u2014for instance:  \n      \u2013 \u03a8+ \u2192 clicks {4,5}  \n      \u2013 \u03a8\u2212 \u2192 clicks {4,6}  \n      \u2013 \u03a6+ \u2192 clicks {5,7}  \n      \u2013 \u03a6\u2212 \u2192 clicks {6,7}  \n  \u2022 loss_func: maximize discrimination (CR) across the four Bell inputs  \n  \u2022 optimizer: L-BFGS-B  \n  \u2022 thresholds: choose high threshold on off\u2010diagonal overlaps to guarantee orthogonality of signatures  \n\nVisualization:  \n      qubit O \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510            \u250c\u2500 detector 4  \n                 \u2572          \u2571   \n                  [linear interferometer mixing 0\u20133]\u2500 detector 5  \n                 \u2571          \u2572   \n      qubit M \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2534\u2500\u2500 ancilla \u2500\u2534\u2500 detector 6  \n                         ancilla \u2500 detector 7  \n\n(Ancilla injections in modes 2&3 feed the same interferometer.)  \n\nWhy novel:  \n1. No existing Pytheus example fuses continuous-wave optical and microwave-photonics channels into a joint measurement device.  \n2. Hybrid Bell analyzers are a key missing primitive for cross-frequency entanglement distribution, enabling teleportation/entanglement-swap across optical and microwave network segments.  \n3. Everything is purely linear optics + post-selection; no cavities, no dynamic feedback, fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s abstract state engine.  \n\nGeneralization & Impact:  \n\u2013 One can trivially extend to higher\u2010dimensional hybrid analyzers, multi\u2010qubit GHZ analyzers, or chains of hybrid swaps.  \n\u2013 This opens a whole family of hybrid\u2010frequency quantum-network experiments (repeaters, routers, mediated gates) within the existing Pytheus framework.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While designing a Bell\u2010state analyzer for a hybrid optical\u2013microwave qubit pair is a potentially useful engineering goal, the proposal is essentially a one\u2010to\u2010one mapping of the well\u2010known all\u2010optical Bell analyzers to a different frequency domain without introducing any new quantum\u2010network feature (no causally indefinite structure, no resource saving over standard designs, no superposition of measurement orders, etc.). Moreover, the scheme lacks any concrete physical mechanism for coherently mixing microwave and optical modes in a purely passive linear network\u2014it simply restates \u201cinsert a beamsplitter\u201d at two wildly different frequencies. As stated, it reads like a trivial domain swap rather than a novel PRL\u2010worthy protocol.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To be considered, you need to identify a genuinely new quantum effect or resource (e.g. entanglement superactivation, indefinite causal order, measurement\u2010based nonlinearity) enabled by the hybrid measurement, and you must specify a realistic interface between microwave and optical modes (for instance via electro\u2010optic converters or optomechanics) rather than assume a \u201cpassive beamsplitter\u201d across frequencies. Without this, the idea is just a straightforward Bell\u2010analyzer generalization.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Proposed Target: Hybrid Optical\u2013Microwave Butterfly Quantum Network Code  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label four end\u2010nodes:  \n\u2022 Sender A (optical qubit mode 0)  \n\u2022 Sender B (optical qubit mode 1)  \n\u2022 Receiver C (microwave qubit mode 2)  \n\u2022 Receiver D (microwave qubit mode 3)  \n\nGoal: Simultaneously transmit an unknown qubit from A\u2192C and from B\u2192D over a single network \u201cbutterfly\u201d resource, using entanglement\u2010assisted network coding.  \n\nResources:  \n  \u2013 Pair\u2010source 1 (optical): modes 0\u20134  \n  \u2013 Pair\u2010source 2 (optical): modes 1\u20135  \n  \u2013 Pair\u2010source 3 (microwave): modes 6\u20132  \n  \u2013 Pair\u2010source 4 (microwave): modes 7\u20133  \n\nIntermediate router node holds modes 4,5,6,7. We inject two ancilla photons into modes 8&9. A single passive interferometer mixes modes [4\u20139] and we place four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors on half of the outputs (anc_detectors = [10,11,12,13]) and two heralded outputs (heralding_out = [14,15]) that carry the corrected qubits forward.  \n\nConfiguration Sketch for Pytheus:  \n  \u2022 in_nodes = [0,1]  \n  \u2022 out_nodes = [2,3]  \n  \u2022 pair_sources at edges: [(0,4),(1,5),(6,2),(7,3)]  \n  \u2022 num_anc = 2 (ancilla injections)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [10,11,12,13]  \n  \u2022 removed_connections = [] (all mixing allowed at router)  \n  \u2022 target_quantum: define four click\u2010patterns on detectors {10\u201313} that herald the correct mapping of the joint input state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_A\u2297\u2223\u03c6\u27e9_B onto outputs at C&D:  \n       \u2013 two patterns correspond to A\u2192C, B\u2192D (butterfly code success), other patterns are discarded.  \n  \u2022 loss_func = cr (maximize conditional routing fidelity)  \n  \u2022 optimizer = L\u2010BFGS\u2010B, number_resolving = True  \n\nVisualization:\n\n    Sender A \u2500\u2500\u2022              \u250c\u2500\u2500 Receiver C  \n                \\            /  \nPair\u2010source (0\u20134)  [ Interferometer + ancilla 8,9 ] \u2500 anc_det [10\u201313]  \n                /            \\  \n    Sender B \u2500\u2500\u2022              \u2514\u2500\u2500 Receiver D  \n\nOperation:  \n  1. A and B each hold an unknown qubit.  \n  2. They tap into two optical EPR links; nodes C and D tap into two microwave EPR links.  \n  3. The router performs a joint linear\u2010optical swap+XOR network code on the four mid\u2010link modes plus ancillas, with post\u2010selected detector patterns.  \n  4. Upon the heralding signals, the unknown qubit from A emerges at C and that from B emerges at D.  \n\nWhy It Fits Pytheus:  \n  \u2013 Abstract pair\u2010sources & detectors only.  \n  \u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2013 Purely linear\u2010optical + ancilla + post\u2010selection.  \n  \u2013 A genuine network\u2010coding transformation, not mere state generation.  \n  \u2013 Directly generalizes to larger hybrid networks and higher\u2010dimensional codes.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While employing a butterfly network code to send two qubits simultaneously is a well-known quantum-network\u2010coding primitive\u2014and in fact very similar to both the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation\u2026\u201d and \u201cButterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\u201d\u2014this proposal adds only a domain swap (optical vs. microwave) without introducing any new network feature, resource saving, or nonclassical causal structure. Moreover, the scheme glosses over the physically critical challenge of coherently mixing microwave and optical modes in a passive interferometer. As stated, it is a trivial generalization of known butterfly codes rather than a PRL\u2010worthy, genuinely novel target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To improve, you must (1) identify a new quantum resource or effect unlocked by the hybrid code (e.g. causally indefinite routing, superactivation, genuine coherent hybrid interface), (2) specify a realistic microwave\u2013optical conversion mechanism rather than assume a passive beamsplitter, and (3) demonstrate a nontrivial advantage (resource reduction or enhanced fidelity) over the existing all-optical butterfly codes already in the literature.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: {\n  \"explanation\": \"We build a four\u2010node \u2018butterfly\u2019 network: two optical senders A(0), B(1) each share CW\u2010SPDC EPR links with a central router via abstract pair sources on modes (0\u20134) and (1\u20135). The router mixes its four mid\u2010link modes 4,5,6,7 together with three ancilla photons (nodes 8,9,10) through a passive linear interferometer. Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors (anc_detectors = [11\u201314]) resolve click patterns that herald the successful network\u2010coding transformation: input qubit at A emerges at C and input at B emerges at D simultaneously, yielding two Bell pairs (A\u2013C and B\u2013D) with only 3 ancillas instead of 4. microwave\u2010swap) or (microwave\u2010swap then optical\u2010swap).  \n\nWe build one static linear optical interferometer that mixes modes [0\u20136] plus two extra ancilla photons (modes 8\u20139) A single static linear\u2010optical interferometer mixes all eleven input modes [0\u201311] and routes six of its outputs into photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors (anc_detectors = [12\u201317]). The remaining two output rails are modes 6\u20137 (O\u2032) and modes 8\u20139 (M\u2032). A specific six\u2010click pattern on detectors 12\u201317 heralds the successful controlled\u2010SWAP.  \n\nVisualization:  \n   emit C \u2500\u2510         \u250c\u2500 dets  \n           \u2572       \u2571   [12\u201314]  \n   emit O \u2500\u25ba [linear interferometer + anc. inj. 10\u201311] \u2500\u25ba dets [15\u201317]  \n           \u2571       \u2572  \n   emit M \u2500\u2518         \u2514\u2500 outputs O\u2032 (6\u20137) & M\u2032 (8\u20139)  \n\nWhy It\u2019s Interesting:  \n \u2022 It\u2019s a true 3\u2010qubit network gate (a quantum router) integrating two different frequency\u2010domain qubits.  \n \u2022 Enables coherent routing of quantum data between optical and microwave segments under quantum control\u2014foundational for future hybrid networks.  \n \u2022 Can be generalized to multi\u2010port routers, higher\u2010dimensional \u201cFredkin\u201d operations, or chained into more complex network codes.  \n\nPytheus Config Sketch:  \n\u2022 description: \u201cHybrid optical\u2013microwave post\u2010selected Fredkin gate\u201d  \n\u2022 foldername: \u201chyb_fredkin_router\u201d  \n\u2022 single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5]                # qubit sources (C,O,M)  \n\u2022 num_anc: 2                                 # ancilla photons in modes 10,11  \n\u2022 in_nodes: [0,2,4]                         # control,C; data O; data M  \n\u2022 out_nodes: [6,8]                          # O\u2032, M\u2032  \n\u2022 anc_detectors: [12,13,14,15,16,17]        # PNR detectors  \n\u2022 removed_connections: []                   # full mixing allowed  \n\u2022 number_resolving: true  \n\u2022 loss_func: \u201ccr\u201d                            # maximize conditional\u2010swap fidelity  \n\u2022 optimizer: \u201cL-BFGS-B\u201d  \n\u2022 target_quantum: list of the eight basis\u2010mapping strings for the Fredkin truth table, e.g.:  \n    \u2013 \u201c000000\u201d\u2192\u201c000000\u201d  \n    \u2013 \u201c001000\u201d\u2192\u201c001000\u201d  \n    \u2013 \u2026  \n    \u2013 \u201c100010\u201d\u2192\u201c100100\u201d  (swap O/M when C=1)  \n    \u2013 \u2026  \n\nThis target invites Pytheus to optimize a passive linear\u2010optical network that implements a hybrid\u2010frequency controlled\u2010SWAP\u2014laying the groundwork for fully quantum\u2010controlled routing between optical and microwave quantum channels.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal is essentially a frequency\u2010domain relabeling of the well\u2010known heralded linear\u2010optical Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) router already in the ensemble (\u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d). Six photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors on modes 9\u201314 herald projection onto the SWITCH\u2019s Choi\u2010state, and the teleported qubit emerges on mode 15 at node C, entangled with the control. Two EPR pair sources create entanglement on modes (1\u20132) [optical domain] and (3\u20134) [microwave domain]. Two ancilla photons on modes 7\u20138 feed the joint measurement. A single static linear-optical network (including an abstract interferometer mixing optical and microwave rails) processes modes 0\u20138. Six photon-number-resolving detectors on modes 9\u201314 herald projection onto the SWITCH\u2019s Choi-state, and the teleported qubit emerges on mode 15 at node C, still entangled with the control. Because the order of swaps is superposed, only two ancillas are needed (instead of four for two fixed-order swaps) and the heralded success probability under asymmetric link losses can exceed that of any fixed-order protocol.     "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Hexapartite steering based on a four-wave-mixing process with a\n  spatially structured pump\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: QDC: Quantum Diffusion Convolution Kernels on Graphs\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Sharing nonlocality in quantum network by unbounded sequential observers\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). Pytheus can model three pair\u2010sources, three BSMs, inputs & outputs as qubits, and ancilla detectors. It\u2019s a protocol, not a fixed-state generation.  \n  C) Frequency\u2010multiplexed routing is appealing but Pytheus cannot model dynamic switching or multiplex selection in one static target.  \nStep 3: Pick B.  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because by chaining three teleportation steps in a closed loop we implement a cyclic permutation of quantum states\u2014an elementary multi\u2010party network primitive that goes beyond end-to-end entanglement or linear chains. Continuous\u2010wave pumped optical links and microwave\u2010photonic links alternate, so we also fuse two very different physical\u2010frequency domains into a single teleportation cycle.  \nStep 5: It\u2019s feasible in Pytheus: treat each link as an abstract two\u2010mode probabilistic pair source, label two as \u201coptical\u201d and one as \u201cmicrowave\u201d only in the interpretation but otherwise identical; perform three Bell measurements via linear optics and post-selection (ancilla detectors); specify three input nodes, three output nodes, number of ancillas = 6, removed_connections to forbid any direct source between non-adjacent nodes; and set the target as a cyclic mapping of the three qubits. Pytheus can optimize the linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters, phase shifters) for this mapping.  \nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nProposed Target: Cyclic Teleportation in a Hybrid Optical\u2013Microwave Three\u2010Node Network  \nExplanation:  \nWe label three parties A, B, C. Each holds one unknown qubit we wish to cyclically shift: A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A. We build three entanglement links:  \n\u2022 Link 1 (optical): CW\u2010pumped SPDC source creating an EPR pair between modes A\u2032 and B\u2032.  \n\u2022 Link 2 (microwave): a parametric microwave\u2010photonic pair source between modes B\u2033 and C\u2032.  \n\u2022 Link 3 (optical): another CW\u2010pumped SPDC pair between modes C\u2033 and A\u2033.  \n\nAt each party we perform a Bell-state measurement (BSM):  \n\u2022 BSM\u2081 on (A, A\u2033),  \n\u2022 BSM\u2082 on (B, B\u2032),  \n\u2022 BSM\u2083 on (C, C\u2032).  \n\nPost-selecting on the appropriate coincidence patterns (6 ancilla detectors in total) effects teleportation of A\u2192B, B\u2192C, and C\u2192A simultaneously. No single source connects any non-adjacent pair (e.g. A\u2192C directly), so all transport is via the cycle.  \n\nKey Pytheus Configuration Sketch:  \n\u2022 num_pre (in_nodes) = 3  (nodes 0,1,2 are inputs A, B, C)  \n\u2022 num_targets (out_nodes) = 3 (nodes 7,8,9 are outputs B, C, A)  \n\u2022 3 pair sources: edges between (3\u20134), (5\u20136), (10\u201311)  \n\u2022 Bell-measurement network connecting input nodes to one half of each pair\u2013source via a linear\u2010optical interferometer to ancilla detectors [12\u201317]  \n\u2022 target_quantum enforces that post-selection yields the joint state |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080\u2081\u2082 at inputs mapped to outputs |\u03c8\u27e9\u2087\u2088\u2089 up to known Pauli corrections (a cyclic shift).  \n\u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct connections among non-adjacent nodes  \n\u2022 number_resolving = True, ample ancillas for heralding  \n\nGeneralization: the same idea scales to longer loops or higher\u2010dimensional cyclic shifts, and one can alternate more optical vs. microwave links for hybrid repeater chains.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The proposed scheme is just three independent teleporters chained into a loop, which is a straightforward generalization of standard teleportation. To be novel, you need a genuinely new network feature (indefinite order, resource reduction, nonclassical causal structure, etc.) rather than a cyclic arrangement of known elements.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:  \nI will propose a concrete Pytheus design target for a novel *hybrid Bell-state analyzer* that sits at the heart of a future optical\u2013microwave quantum network.  This network primitive\u2014never before implemented in linear-optical toolbox designs\u2014would let one unambiguously discriminate all four Bell states of a qubit pair where one qubit travels in a continuous-wave\u2013SPDC optical channel and the other in a microwave-photonics channel.  Such a hybrid analyzer directly enables entanglement swapping or teleportation between optical and microwave nodes, is purely linear-optical/post-selection (no cavities or feedback), uses ancilla photons, and generalizes the Yeo-Chua/King\u2019s\u2010Problem analyzers already in Pytheus but to a new frequency-hybrid domain.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nProposed Target: Hybrid Optical\u2013Microwave Bell-State Analyzer  \n\nExplanation:  \nWe label two input qubits:  \n\u2022 Mode O (optical qubit from a CW-pumped SPDC source, dual\u2010rail encoding)  \n\u2022 Mode M (microwave-photonics qubit from a parametric down-conversion source, dual-rail encoding)  \n\nGoal: design a linear network + ancilla-photon injections + photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors that, upon post\u2010selecting certain click patterns, yields four disjoint heralding signatures\u2014one for each Bell state  \n\u03a8\u00b1 = \u22230_O0_M\u27e9\u00b1\u22231_O1_M\u27e9,  \n\u03a6\u00b1 = \u22230_O1_M\u27e9\u00b1\u22231_O0_M\u27e9.  \n\nThis is the \u201ccomplete Bell\u2010state measurement\u201d for a hybrid-domain pair.  With this analyzer in hand, one can then do mode-domain entanglement swapping or teleportation between optical and microwave network nodes simply by projecting onto these four outcomes.  \n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:  \n  \u2022 in_nodes = [0,1]  (qubit rails of O and M)  \n  \u2022 single_emitters: optional; but more naturally modeled as two pair\u2010sources feeding ancillary modes  \n  \u2022 num_anc = 2 (two ancilla photons injected in modes 2&3)  \n  \u2022 anc_detectors = [4,5,6,7] (number\u2010resolving detectors)  \n  \u2022 removed_connections: none (all mixing allowed)  \n  \u2022 target_quantum: design a mapping so that each Bell basis input is routed to a unique 4-detector click pattern\u2014for instance:  \n      \u2013 \u03a8+ \u2192 clicks {4,5}  \n      \u2013 \u03a8\u2212 \u2192 clicks {4,6}  \n      \u2013 \u03a6+ \u2192 clicks {5,7}  \n      \u2013 \u03a6\u2212 \u2192 clicks {6,7}  \n  \u2022 loss_func: maximize discrimination (CR) across the four Bell inputs  \n  \u2022 optimizer: L-BFGS-B  \n  \u2022 thresholds: choose high threshold on off\u2010diagonal overlaps to guarantee orthogonality of signatures  \n\nVisualization:  \n      qubit O \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510            \u250c\u2500 detector 4  \n                 \u2572          \u2571   \n                  [linear interferometer mixing 0\u20133]\u2500 detector 5  \n                 \u2571          \u2572   \n      qubit M \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2534\u2500\u2500 ancilla \u2500\u2534\u2500 detector 6  \n                         ancilla \u2500 detector 7  \n\n(Ancilla injections in modes 2&3 feed the same interferometer.)  \n\nWhy novel:  \n1. No existing Pytheus example fuses continuous-wave optical and microwave-photonics channels into a joint measurement device.  \n2. Hybrid Bell analyzers are a key missing primitive for cross-frequency entanglement distribution, enabling teleportation/entanglement-swap across optical and microwave network segments.  \n3. Everything is purely linear optics + post-selection; no cavities, no dynamic feedback, fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s abstract state engine.  \n\nGeneralization & Impact:  \n\u2013 One can trivially extend to higher\u2010dimensional hybrid analyzers, multi\u2010qubit GHZ analyzers, or chains of hybrid swaps.  \n\u2013 This opens a whole family of hybrid\u2010frequency quantum-network experiments (repeaters, routers, mediated gates) within the existing Pytheus framework.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be considered, you need to identify a genuinely new quantum effect or resource (e.g. entanglement superactivation, indefinite causal order, measurement\u2010based nonlinearity) enabled by the hybrid measurement, and you must specify a realistic interface between microwave and optical modes (for instance via electro\u2010optic converters or optomechanics) rather than assume a \u201cpassive beamsplitter\u201d across frequencies.
